I will not be the first to praise this game, and most likely will not be the last. This alone speaks to the transcendence this game has achieved. Each part of this game has been intricately developed, way ahead of its time. Half-Life has reached a level of excellence rarely seen in its time and genre, and has led to a mass exodus of well developed games. I can, without a doubt, attribute the title of gem to this game.

Half-Life is a science-fiction story about Gordon Freeman, who is a scientist working in a research facility, and is the stories' protagonist. One day, when Gordon arrives at the installation, an experiment is scheduled. Assisted by his colleagues, Gordon joins the experiment.

The world is seen from the protagonist's own viewpoint.
During play, the protagonist makes a continuous journey through contiguous environments, which drives the story onwards. The protagonist may be moved to travel in all directions, on foot, through liquids, or by vehicles. The protagonist may also wear and carry items, mostly firearms, protection, and tools.
The environments are interactive, and have hazards that must be overcome. The protagonist may fail, but progress is kept safe and allows continuation.

The protagonist may engage with various actors, who may interact with the environment and with each other, by making use of ingenious dialogue, or by talking to, or mentioning the protagonist. This interaction between these characters is immersive.
The protagonist controls direct, immediate, and precise, which is practical for aiming, navigating, and avoiding hazards.
Half-Life is inspiring, and can be played with others and modified. Install [i]Half-Life SDK[/i] from the [i]tools section[/i] in the [i]Steam library[/i], to gain access to the world-editor.

I played Half-Life 2 and the episodes for as long as I had been actually playing videogames, when I got it on the Orange Box with the original intent of playing Portal 2. I loved how it encouraged thought and using the environment in new and interesting ways in order to get past the forces in your path. I loved the story despite the missing portion of the Black Mesa incident having never played the original game.

About three days ago I sold an item on the marketplace for about $10.00 and I decided that I would pick up this game which has been a gap in my experience with the series, and shooters as a whole. I did not, and never will, regret that decision.

Half-Life still holds up despite its date of release in 1998, but not in a graphical or bugwise sense. It brings to the table that wonderful thought-provoking gameplay that encompasses everything from strategic planning and resource management, to quick well-honed reflexes and snap decisions. The troubles you face while battling through Black Mesa rarely give way to brute force, but instead to cunning, rational reasoning, and even some of the most outrageous and ridiculous "Hail Mary"s I have ever had the pleasure of conceiving.

If you can manage to get over occasional confusing level design and the [spoiler] frustrating, boring, and slow-paced Xen levels, [/spoiler] I'm sure anyone with the desire to spend 10-15 hours on this game (or more for replays) will have an excellent time.

For the best experience, play blindly, with no walkthroughs, on hard mode. It will get frustrating, sure, but remember there is always a solution. Finding these solutions is a source of immense satisfaction, fulfillment, and excitement. You will not regret the experience.
On a Rail makes me want to smash my balls with a hammer

Half Life is one of the most known shooters of all time. Half life is a story game where Gordon Freeman works at Black mesa and fucks up and causes a Resonance Cascade. You cannot forget the world of half life, the enemies, the allies, the maps, and last but not least, the guns. You can run Half life on everything most likely, just ask your mom to buy you something that a homeless guy offered you for 300 bucks and you could probably run this game. While Half life is probably older than you and me, it still holds up as an amazing game and if you haven't played it, please check it out. The world building in this game is insane and has a great story if you pay close attention. The guns in this game are fantastic to use and there are 14 different weapons to use. The allies in enemies are unforgetable with the Scientists, the Security Guards, The Imposing force/MECU Soldiers, Creatures from Xen, and even the Black ops soldiers. The game can be hard and it's very unforgiving and you have to stay on your toes throughout the whole experience. The gunplay feels amazing and still holds up to this day. Though, all amazing games have flaws. The Xen part of this game is extremely long and boring and the graphics suck balls. The overall graphics of this game are shit but still good for its time. A few parts in this game like on a rail can seem extremely boring and tedious. And sometimes the game breaks and does random shit.

Overall I'd say this game is currently a 79/100 but for its time a def 95/100. If you cannot bear the graphics I recommend playing Black mesa.

One of the greatest and most influential FPS games of all time. When it first came out Half-Life revolutionized the FPS genre. And still to this day, you can feel it's effects on many FPS games. Before Half-Life there was DOOM, Wolfenstein. These games were just about running and gunning. Half-Life changed that formula. You can see that in the opening section in the game. Half-Life slowed down the gameplay and added more elements. In Half-Life, you have to be tactical. You can't rush into every enemy otherwise you'll be dead before you know it. You have to use every tool in your arsenal to get out of tricky situations. Half-Life was a huge deal back then and now years later playing it feels really good. The soundtrack is good, weapons sounds are great and gunplay is amazing. Level design is superb. There are platforming sections, stealth sections, creepy sections, we have lots of variety. The story is well written, characters are memorable. Mysterious G-Man, security guard Barney, protagonist Gordon Freeman, everyone has a charm to them. Enemy design is great. Headcrabs, houndeyes, every alien has a distinct feature and distinct behaviour. This game was ahead of its time, and it shows. It really is a masterpiece and better than most of the FPS games come out nowadays. If you are a FPS game fan and haven't played it, you definitely should play it. Half-Life is and always will be every FPS lover's favourite game.

Half-Life is an old game with dated graphics, but the gameplay is still great. There are many varying locations to explore and many different weapons with unique mechanics to collect. The difficulty varies between different areas throughout the story. Some areas give you plenty of ammunition, and others don't. I got this game cheap from the Valve Complete Pack, and as a whole I would recommend it.

This game literally made my life in the way it is. So brilliant.

Half Life is a solid game and I wholeheartedly think this game is worth your time

But that aside, I'd just like to take a moment and appreciate the fact that this game is still accessible today. Think about it, a nearly 23 year old game can still be bought through official means, and still runs perfectly on modern hardware without workarounds. I can't overstate how much of a godsend this is, especially considering how other games from around that same time can't even be played nowadays without older operating systems or even older hardware in some cases. Hell, even games that came out way after Half-Life still sometimes have issues with modern hardware. Crysis can't even run on Windows 10 systems without workarounds, yet Half-Life just runs out of the box. Had this game not have been easily accessible, it wouldn't have as big of a legacy as it currently does 

So thank Valve for keeping your old games alive, If only more companies could do the same...

a really good game despite it being very old, id recommend half life to anyone, but you need to know how to play the game right to actually have fun. if you play this game like DOOM (guns blazing) then you're gonna die a lot and be frustrated. you gotta put yourself in gordons shoes to actually have fun, play smart. an extremely useful video that i highly recommend watching (there might be spoilers) really helped be and i wish i found it before i played (there might be spoilers) (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dg5EQyw_7Hk). like what LeadHead said, "Gordon isn't a soldier, he's a scientist."
Ah another day at the job, this is good for those with brains.

This game is really, really fun, but you need to put yourself into the right mindset to play it. It's not an easy game by any means- especially if you treat it like a normal FPS. I found an amazing video explaining Half Life, and the mindset you should use to beat it. Link here (All credit goes to Leadhead) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dg5EQyw_7Hk&t=108s     This video sums up most of my review, so I'll add a couple more things. You can skip past most aliens in the game (Ex. headcrabs) but in most situations you CANNOT skip past soliders or alien grunts. I realize I can't go much farther without heavily spoiling gameplay, so I'll just end it here. All in all, Half Life really is an amazing game and ten dollars, even now, is a steal.

Damn, I thought HL2 was good, but this is is even older and still plays fantastically. Yeah ok, it's not HL2, but don't ever go around thinking that the first game is not worth playing, because it 100% is. If I had played this when it came out in 1998, I would have thought that it was the greatest game of all time. I'm still blown away by just how good it is. 9/10
